title: Ellis Spear
text:
Ellis Spear (October 15, 1834 – April 3, 1917) was an officer in the <a href="20th%20Maine%20Volunteer%20Infantry%20Regiment">20th Maine Volunteer Infantry Regiment</a> of the <a href="Union%20Army">Union Army</a> during the <a href="American%20Civil%20War">American Civil War</a>. On April 10, 1866, the <a href="United%20States%20Senate">United States Senate</a> confirmed <a href="President%20of%20the%20United%20States">President</a> <a href="Andrew%20Johnson">Andrew Johnson's</a> February 24, 1866 nomination of Spear for appointment to the grade of <a href="Brevet%20%28military%29">brevet</a> <a href="Brigadier%20general%20%28United%20States%29">brigadier general</a> to rank from April 9, 1865. He was <a href="United%20States%20Commissioner%20of%20Patents">United States Commissioner of Patents</a> in 1877-1878.
Early life.
Spear was born on October 15, 1834 in <a href="Warren%2C%20Maine">Warren, Maine</a> where he grew up on his family's farm and attended a <a href="Presbyterian%20church">Presbyterian church</a> Sunday School. Spear received his higher education at <a href="Bowdoin%20College">Bowdoin College</a>, graduating in 1858. Spear taught in local schools for four years while also studying law. 
American Civil War.
During the second year of the Civil War he became a recruiter and formed Company G of the 20th Maine Volunteer Infantry Regiment. Spear was commissioned as a <a href="captain%20%28United%20States%29">captain</a> of the regiment, August 29, 1862. He was promoted to <a href="Major%20%28United%20States%29">major</a>, August 28, 1863. He was appointed brevet <a href="Lieutenant%20colonel%20%28United%20States%29">lieutenant colonel</a>, to rank from September 30, 1864, for his service at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Peeble%27s%20Farm">Battle of Peeble's Farm</a>. Spear was appointed brevet <a href="Colonel%20%28United%20States%29">colonel</a>, to rank from May 29, 1865, for his service at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Lewis%27s%20Farm">Battle of Lewis's Farm</a> and to the substantive full grade of colonel, to rank from the same date. He took command of Brigade 2, Division 4, <a href="V%20Corps%20%28Union%20Army%29">V Corps (Union Army)</a>, <a href="Army%20of%20the%20Potomac">Army of the Potomac</a> on June 29, 1865. He was mustered out of the volunteers on July 16, 1865.
On February 24, 1866, President Andrew Johnson nominated Spear for appointment to the grade of <a href="Brevet%20%28military%29">brevet</a> <a href="Brigadier%20general%20%28United%20States%29">brigadier general</a> of volunteers, to rank from April 9, 1865, and the United States Senate confirmed the appointment on April 10, 1866.
Later life.
After the war, Spear became a patent attorney and eventually became the <a href="United%20States%20Commissioner%20of%20Patents">United States Commissioner of Patents</a>, 1877-1878. He also wrote about the war. His book, "The Civil War Recollections of General Ellis Spear" was published posthumously in 1998.
Spear wrote that he believed that many members of the 20th Maine, particularly Colonel <a href="Joshua%20Lawrence%20Chamberlain">Joshua Lawrence Chamberlain</a>, exaggerated their roles at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Gettysburg">Battle of Gettysburg</a> actions at <a href="Little%20Round%20Top">Little Round Top</a> and at <a href="Battle%20of%20Fredericksburg">Battle of Fredericksburg</a>. Nevertheless, Spear and Chamberlain remained close friends until Chamberlain's death in 1914.
Spear died in <a href="St.%20Petersburg%2C%20Florida">St. Petersburg, Florida</a> on April 3, 1917. He was buried at <a href="Arlington%20National%20Cemetery">Arlington National Cemetery</a>. His papers were later published by his grandson, Abbot Spear.
Gettysburg Film.
Spear was played by <a href="Donal%20Logue">Donal Logue</a> in the 1993 film "<a href="Gettysburg%20%281993%20film%29">Gettysburg</a>" and by Jonathan Maxwell in "<a href="Gods%20and%20Generals%20%28film%29">Gods and Generals</a>".
